title: No GST Plans for UPI Transactions Over ₹2,000, Finance Ministry Clarifies
summary: The Indian Finance Ministry has strongly denied reports claiming the government is considering implementing GST on UPI transactions exceeding ₹2,000. The ministry stated these claims are completely false and misleading, emphasizing that no such proposal exists. The government continues to promote digital payments through UPI with various incentive schemes.
content:
The government has officially denied media reports suggesting plans to levy goods and services tax (GST) on UPI transactions over ₹2,000. The finance ministry issued a clear statement on April 18 declaring these claims as "completely false, misleading, and without any basis."

Earlier reports had suggested that digital payments via UPI exceeding ₹2,000 might be subject to an 18% GST rate to enhance tax compliance. However, the finance ministry clarified that since no Merchant Discount Rate (MDR) is currently charged on UPI transactions, no GST is consequently applicable.

The government has demonstrated its commitment to promoting digital payments through various initiatives. A government-led incentive scheme has been operational since FY 2021-22, with increasing allocations each year: ₹1,389 crore in FY2021-22, ₹2,210 crore in FY2022-23, and ₹3,631 crore in FY2023-24.

India's digital payment ecosystem has shown remarkable growth, with the country accounting for 49% of global real-time transactions in 2023, according to the ACI Worldwide Report 2024. UPI transaction values have grown exponentially from ₹21.3 lakh crore in FY 2019-20 to ₹260.56 lakh crore by March 2025, with Person-to-Merchant transactions reaching ₹59.3 lakh crore.

content.content:
GST on UPI payments:The government has denied media reports claiming it is considering proposals to levygoods and services tax (GST)onunified payments interface (UPI)transactions exceeding₹2,000. The finance ministry clarified on April 18 that claims that it is considering levying GST on UPI transactions over₹2,000 are “completely false, misleading, and without any basis.” Currently, no such proposal is before the government.

Earlier today, certain media reports claimed thatdigital paymentsmade via UPI exceeding the₹2,000 threshold in a single transaction may be brought under the GST framework for compliance. This aimed to enhance tax compliance and bring more digital transactions into the formal economy.

“If approved, an 18 per cent GST, the standard rate for most digital services, could be levied on high-value transactions. The proposal is still under consideration. The move could significantly shift India’s UPI ecosystem, which has been a cost-free, user-friendly platform,” claimed the reports.

The finance ministry said that GST is levied on charges, such as the Merchant Discount Rate (MDR), relating to payments made using certain instruments. Effective January 2020, theCentral Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT)has removed the MDR on Person-to-Merchant (P2M) UPI transactions through the Gazette Notification dated December 30, 2019.

Since no MDR is currently charged on UPI transactions, no GST is consequently applicable. The government remainscommittedto promoting digital payments via UPI. A government-led incentive scheme has been operational from FY 2021-22 to support and sustain UPI's growth.

“This scheme targets low-value UPI (P2M) transactions, benefiting small merchants by alleviating transaction costs and promoting wider participation and innovation in digital payments,” said the finance ministry.

The total incentive payouts under this scheme over the years reflect the Government’s sustained commitment to promoting UPI-based digital payments. Allocation under the scheme over the years has been:

• FY2021-22:₹1,389 crore

• FY2022-23:₹2,210 crore

• FY2023-24:₹3,631 crore

These measures have significantly contributed to India’s robust digital payments ecosystem. According to the ACI Worldwide Report 2024, India accounted for 49 per cent of global real-time transactions in 2023, reaffirming its position as a global leader in digital payments innovation.

UPI transactionvalues have increased exponentially, from₹21.3 lakh crore in FY 2019-20 to₹260.56 lakh crore by March 2025. Specifically, P2M transactions have reached₹59.3 lakh crore, reflecting growing merchant adoption and consumer confidence in digital payment methods.

## Official Clarification
The government has officially denied media reports suggesting plans to levy goods and services tax (GST) on UPI transactions over ₹2,000. The finance ministry issued a clear statement on April 18 declaring these claims as "completely false, misleading, and without any basis."

Earlier reports had suggested that digital payments via UPI exceeding ₹2,000 might be subject to an 18% GST rate to enhance tax compliance. However, the finance ministry clarified that since no Merchant Discount Rate (MDR) is currently charged on UPI transactions, no GST is consequently applicable.

## Government Support for Digital Payments
The government has demonstrated its commitment to promoting digital payments through various initiatives. A government-led incentive scheme has been operational since FY 2021-22, with increasing allocations each year:
* ₹1,389 crore in FY2021-22
* ₹2,210 crore in FY2022-23
* ₹3,631 crore in FY2023-24

## Digital Payment Growth
India's digital payment ecosystem has shown remarkable growth, with the country accounting for 49% of global real-time transactions in 2023, according to the ACI Worldwide Report 2024. UPI transaction values have grown exponentially from ₹21.3 lakh crore in FY 2019-20 to ₹260.56 lakh crore by March 2025, with Person-to-Merchant transactions reaching ₹59.3 lakh crore.
